titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Miguel A. Gandert Photographs and Papers
titlestmt.author: Matthew Daniel Mason and Danijela True

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday January 29, 2019 at 04:17

did.unittitle: Miguel A. Gandert photographs and papers

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.physdesc: (114 boxes) + 8 broadsides, 7 broadsides oversize
did.abstract: The collection consists of photographic prints (chiefly in black and white), contact sheets, printed material, and computer disks.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Boxes 27, 28, 87, 102, 129 (sound recordings and computer disks): Restricted Fragile Material. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Miguel A. Gandert Photographs and Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Miguel A. Gandert Photographs and Papers. Yale Collection of Western Americana, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels, depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived research value, the availability of staff, competing priorities, and whether or not further accruals are expected. The library attempts to provide a basic level of preservation and access for all collections as they are acquired, and does more extensive processing of higher priority collections as time and resources permit.

This collection received a basic level of processing, including rehousing and minimal organization in 2007, and again in 2014. Various acquisitions associated with the collection have not been merged and organized as a whole. Each acquisition is described separately in the contents list below, titled according to month and year of acquisition.

Information included in the Description of Papers note and Collection Contents section is drawn from information supplied with the collection and from an initial survey of the contents. Folder titles appearing in the contents list below are often based on those provided by the creator or previous custodian. Titles have not been verified against the contents of the folders in all cases. Otherwise, folder titles are supplied by staff during initial processing.
This finding aid may be updated periodically to account for new acquisitions to the collection and/or revisions in arrangement and description.
Former call numbers: Uncat MSS 24, Uncat MSS 290, Uncat MSS 585, Uncat MSS 787, and Uncat MSS 1042

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of photographs and papers that document the work of Miguel A. Gandert recording mestizo culture in the Rio Grande region of the American Southwest, including the landscapes and people of Northern New Mexico, circa 1972-2006. Many of the images depict individuals underdocumented in mainstream society, including boxers, Mexican immigrants, motorcycle gang members, teenage mothers, and urban Mexican American youth. The collection consists of photographs, including contact sheets, work prints, transparencies, and exhibition prints, as well as computer media and publications with images created by Gandert.

Material in the collection includes photographic work from college and graduate school at the University of New Mexico, circa 1972-1983, as well as his exhibitions and publications through 2006. Exhibitions documented include Boxers and Wrestlers (1977), Being With It (1979), Let's Boogie at Okie's (1980), Varrio San José: Scenes from an Urban Chicano Experience (1980-1983), Tierra O Muerte (1988), Reflexiones del Corazón (1992), Face of a Community (1994), Nuevo México Profundo (2000), and Hermanitos Comanchitos (2003).
In this guide to the collection, library staff retained Gandert's titles and spellings.

Except where noted, photographic prints in the collection are black-and-white prints. Chronological arrangements within the collection are by the image creation date not the date the photograph was printed.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Miguel Gandert on the Frederick W. and Carrie S. Beinecke Fund for Western Americana, 1999-2006, and on the Arthur Corbitt Hoskins Memorial Fund, 2003.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into five groupings: I. September 1999 Acquisition, 1972-1999. II. May 2002 Acquisition, 1980-1999. III. November 2003 Acquisition, 1982-2001. IV. June 2005 Acquisition, 1983-2003. V. December 2006 Acquisition, 1986-2005.

bioghist.head: Miguel A. Gandert (born 1956)
bioghist.p: Miguel A. Gandert is an Indo-Hispano American photographer and photojournalist. Born in Española, New Mexico, Gandert earned a Master of Arts in photography from the University of New Mexico in 1983. His work has appeared in many exhibitions including the National Museum of American History at the Smithsonian in 1990, the 1993 Biennial at the Whitney Museum of American Art, and at the National Hispanic Cultural Center of New Mexico in 2000.

In 1991, Gandert became a professor at the University of New Mexico, eventually the Distinguished Professor of Communication and Journalism. In 2011 he became the director of the Interdisciplinary Film and Digital Media Program.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The September 1999 Acquisition documents Gandert's work as a student at the University of New Mexico and other projects from 1972-1999. It chiefly contains black-and-white photographic prints with a few Cibachrome color prints, as well as printed material and audiovisual material.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Boxes 27 and 28 (sound recordings): Restricted fragile material. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three subseries: Photographs, Printed Material, and Audiovisual Material.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized under eight headings: Two Corners of a Ring / Youth Boxing , Two Corners of a Ring / Championship Wrestling , Being With It , Ecuador, Let's Boogie at Okie's , Varrio San José: Scenes from an Urban Chicano Experience , Face of a Community , followed by a heading for Miscellaneous Prints.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries chronologically documents the photographic work of Gandert, as well as publications that reproduced his images, from 1972 to 1999.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries documents an exhibition that explores land rights disputes in New Mexico, in particular the Tierra Amarilla land grant occupation in 1967. The photographs cheifly include portraits of land rights activists, including Reies López Tijerina and Amador Flores.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries documents a collaborative project by Gandert with the author Gabriel Melendez and the artist Maria Baca at the Tamarind Institute in Albuquerque, New Mexico. The images depict Hispanic culture in the New Mexico cities of Española and Mora, as well as the Barelas neighborhood of Albuquerque.

did.physdesc: This subseries consists of photographic prints, 11 inches by 14 inches.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of work prints for Gandert's co-authored book with Enrique R. Lamadrid, Nuevo México Profundo: Rituals of an Indo-Hispano Homeland . The images and the published work document the religious traditions and customs of the mestizo people of the Upper Rio Grande region of Mexico and New Mexico.
Each photographic print includes a slip from the publisher of the work, Museum of New Mexico Press, which indicates the figure number and page number where the image appeared in the book.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in the order the images appear in the book, followed by prints not included in it.

scopecontent.p: This group of black-and-white and color photographic prints are images that appeared in Gandert's co-authored book with Enrique R. Lamadrid, Nuevo México Profundo: Rituals of an Indo-Hispano Homeland . The image and the work document the religious traditions and customs of the mestizo people of the Upper Rio Grande region of Mexico and New Mexico.

did.physdesc: This group of material consists of photographic prints, 11 inches by 14 inches.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This group of photographs comes from an exhibition that explores land rights disputes in New Mexico. These images were part of a exhibition related to Emiliano Zapata, a leading figure in the Mexican Revolution and the founder of the agrarian movement called Zapatismo. The exhibit occurred at the Johnson Gallery at the University New Mexico in Albuquerque in 2005.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This group of photographs comes from an exhibition depicting rituals of Indo-Hispanic people. The exhibit occurred at the National Hispanic Culture Center of New Mexico, Albuquerque, in 2000-2001. Many photographs appeared in Gandert's co-authored book of the same title.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This group of photographs documents public squares and spaces in New Mexico. They appeared in Gandert's co-authored book, The Plazas of New Mexico , as well as in an exhibition at Pearl Hall, School of Architecture, University of New Mexico, Albuquerque, October 2011.

Bolivia and Mexico, Prints for a Fondation Henri Cartier-Bresson Award
did.physdesc: This group of material consists of photographic prints, 11 inches by 14 inches.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This group of photographs gathered by Gandert relates to an entry for an award from the Fondation Henri Cartier-Bresson. The images document celebrations in Bolivia, including Carnaval de Oruro and La Fiesta del Señor Jesús del Gran Poder in La Paz, as well as a wheat harvest. The group also includes images from an Easter Celebration in Juárez, Mexico.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized under three headings: Carnaval de Oruro, La Fiesta del Señor Jesús del Gran Poder, and Other Prints.

unittitle.title: Gifts of the Land: New Mexico's Farm and Ranch Women

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This group of photographs consists of portraits of New Mexican farm and ranch women, circa 2001-2004, from an oral history project and planned traveling exhibition in collaboration with Glenda Balas.

unittitle.title: Llano Estacado: An Island in the Sky

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized under two headings by print size: 14 inches by 20 inches and 16 inches by 20 inches.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This group of photographs consists of work prints that depict the Llano Estacado (Spanish for palisaded plain), also known as the Staked Plain, a region in the Southwestern United States that encompasses parts of eastern New Mexico and northwestern Texas. The images relate to a project sponsored by the Southwest Center at Texas Tech University and were exhibited at the Houston Photofest in 2006. Images also appeared in Steve Bogener, William E. Tydeman, and Barry Holstun Lopez, Llano Estacado: An Island in the Sky (Lubbock: Texas Tech University Press, 2011).
